item.title: Spend your summer in Sicily.
item.description:
Calling gelato lovers everywhere…

Pack your bags—we’re heading to Palermo, Italy!

The island of Sicily is well-known for its delicious food, fantastic beach weather, and rich history. We’ll be spending 12 weeks there so you have enough time to learn why Palermo was just selected as the Italian Capital of Culture for 2018.

If nothing else, watch this video:


While you can circle the island in a day, there are countless places to visit, foods to eat, people to meet, and things to experience.

Apply here before spots run out. This is not a trip you will want to miss!

More details below.

Palermo, Italy (June 4 – August 26)

Located in the heart of the Mediterranean, Sicily is a bustling island made up of miles of coastline, picturesque mountains, and Mount Etna—the tallest active volcano in Europe.

Hello, sunshine! We will be in Palermo during the driest and sunniest part of the year. With the ocean water between 21-26 C (70-79 F) and one of the best beaches only 20 minutes away, you will have a hard time staying out of the water.

Take your pick between beautiful sandy beaches and rugged fishing villages. Eat fresh seafood while you watch the sunset. Your Instagram will never be the same.

Sorry, mom—in Sicily it’s totally appropriate to have an ice cream sandwich or ‘brioche col gelato’ for breakfast. You’ll wonder how you ever lived without it all these years.

Cannoli, arancini, seafood pasta, and savory pizza. There are too many good foods to list. I’m going to leave this gem of 23 Sicilian Dishes To Die For here for you. Insider tip: don’t read it on an empty stomach.

Need a tasty bite on the go? Forbes listed Palermo as one of The World’s Top 10 Cities for Street Food.

The wine—need I say more? Over the summer, you’ll share countless bottles of wine while learning to enjoy the Italian pace of life. Goodbye, stress.

Interested in seeing ancient ruins? Look no further. Sicily has some of the best-preserved Greek and Roman ruins not only in all of Italy—but in all of Europe.

Hit up the outdoor markets during the day to barter for spices, fresh seafood, or local handcrafts. Come back after sunset to meet up with Sicilians drinking 1€ wine, eating tasty street food, and enjoying the vibrant night life.

It’s Western. Wait, that’s Islamic. No, that looks more like Byzantine architecture. Welcome to the unique style of Sicilian architecture that incorporates elements from all of the different cultures that have occupied the island at some point in history.

Join in the celebration during Palermo’s biggest festival of the year. During the Feast of Santa Rosalia, Palermo’s streets are alive with music, shows, dancing, fireworks, and a parade led by a ten-meter tall vessel-shaped chariot pulled by oxen.

Watch an opera or ballet at the Teatro Massimo, the first opera house in Italy and the third largest opera house in Europe, or catch the Sicilian symphony orchestra at the Teatro Politeama Garibaldi.

“I’m gonna make him an offer he can’t refuse.” Fans of The Godfather can go visit the hometown of the Corleone family and see locations where the trilogy was filmed.

Need a break from all this culture? The rugged nature of Sicily provides plenty of opportunities to get your adrenaline fix while rafting, rock climbing, mountain biking, cliff diving, hiking volcanoes or driving—the ultimate Italian adventure.

Fancy a weekend on Ibiza, the Croatian coast, or some idyllic Greek islands? Maybe you’d rather experience Rome or live it up in Amsterdam, Madrid, or Paris. They are all a quick flight away and you can find roundtrip tickets for under 200€.

item.title: Announcing our Open Source Fellowship
item.description:
Want to spend a month in South America, expenses paid, working on Open Source?

We’re excited to announce that we’re partnering with Changelog to offer two Open Source Fellowships for our upcoming trip to South America!

At Hacker Paradise, we’re big fans of the open source community.

When we launched our very first trip back in 2014, a lot of the people crazy enough to join us came from the open source world. Now that we’re a bit more mature as an organization, we want to give back.

The Open Source Fellowships will cover a month of accommodations, workspace, our events, and a stipend for living expenses for you to join our South America trip and work full-time on an open source project of your choosing.

Also, our friends at Changelog will be following along and will be producing a few podcasts to help tell the OSS story for those who get selected for this fellowship.

We hope that this will give you an excuse to take some time off from work and focus full-time on an open source project that you care about!

What are we looking for?

Mainly, we’d like to maximize the impact these fellowships can have on the open source community.

To that end, we’re looking for maintainers or contributors to popular projects who have 1-2 major ideas they’ve been meaning to implement, but haven’t had the time to do so outside of work. We’re also open to people who are less engaged in open source, but who would like to dive in more fully and spend a month working exclusively on a new or existing project.

Another thing we’ll be looking at is the scope of the project. We want to make sure it’s something that one could feasibly finish or make significant progress on in a month.

Finally, we’re looking for people who are willing and able to focus on open source full-time for a month and who wouldn’t be able to otherwise do so. If your company pays you to work on open source, or if you’d like to freelance part-time while traveling with us, please apply as a normal participant.

Oh, and of course, we’re looking for people who are looking for an adventure!

Logistics

Recipients of the Open Source Fellowship will have the option of joining us for a month on one of our upcoming trips to Buenos Aires, Argentina (Jan 8 - March 4, 2017) or Lima, Peru (March 12 - May 6, 2017).

The fellowship includes accommodations (private bedroom), workspace, and our program fee for one month ($1,980 total), as well as a $750 stipend for food and basic living expenses.

Recipients of the fellowship are responsible for getting to / from the destination, and for any travel, food, and entertainment expenses in excess of the stipend.

Right now, we’re planning to give away two fellowships, although the final number could go up or down depending on applications.

To find out more about Hacker Paradise, check out the following links:

  • Meet some of our alumni
  • Find out more about our South America trips
  • Check out our answers to some frequently asked questions

How do I apply?

When you’re ready, you can apply here for the fellowship.

After you’ve applied, we’ll review your application. If we think you might be a good fit, we’ll schedule an interview to get to know you a bit better and to find out more about your project.

We will accept applications until December 21, 2016. We’ll be interviewing applicants on a rolling basis, so we recommend applying sooner rather than later.

We’re excited to see how this program develops! If your company would be interested in sponsoring an Open Source Fellowship for future trips, send us an email and we can pass along information.

(also, we want to give a hat-tip to Stripe and their Open Source Retreat as the inspiration for this idea)

item.title: Updated FAQ
item.description:
People ask a lot of the same questions in interviews, so we decided to put together a list of the most common ones and write an update to our FAQ! Read on below for answers to the following questions:

  • What kinds of people come to Hacker Paradise?
  • How big are the groups?
  • What do you look for in applicants?
  • I’m not a programmer / designer / entrepreneur. Can I come?
  • How is Hacker Paradise different than ____?
  • What’s a typical day like?
  • Where are you going next and when are you announcing it?
  • What is included in the price?
  • What will I do for transportation?

What kinds of people come to Hacker Paradise?

Most of the people who come on our trips can be split into 3 buckets:

  • Freelancers – people who work remotely for 1 or more clients on a contract basis
  • Remote workers - people who have 1 company that they work for full-time
  • Entrepreneurs - people who are running their company remotely
  • People on sabbatical – people who have decided to take some time off between switching jobs or take an extended vacation to work on their own personal projects

In terms of profession, the majority of people who come on our trips are developers, designers, or entrepreneurs. We also take other creative types, like writers, architects, project managers, photographers, etc., as long as they’re comfortable in a community with a focus on tech & startups.

Many of the people on our trips are from the U.S.A, Canada, or Europe, but we also get people from all over the world, including places like Chile, Ecuador, India, Thailand, Zimbabwe, and Lebanon. Our alumni community hails from 35+ countries.

The majority of our participants are in their 20s and 30s, but we’ve had people on our trip ranging from 18 to 60 years old. We’ve even had a few families come with children as young as 8 months.

We don’t care about where you’re from or your age as long as you are a creative professional that we feel is a good fit for the community!

How big are your trips?

Groups are typically 30-35 people, but they are sometimes a bit bigger or smaller. We tend to not get too much bigger than this, as we’ve noticed in the past that the group dynamic changes once we get higher than 35-40 people. With 30-40 people, there is enough diversity within the group to find people who are interested in the same things as you, but the group is small enough that you still know everyone and the community doesn’t splinter off into different cliques.

What do you look for in applicants?

The first thing we look for in prospective applicants is some kind of generative, creative skillset, like programming, design, writing, etc. We want everyone who comes to be able to create something while with us and potentially collaborate with others on the trip.

Along those lines, we also look for a history of creating things, particularly passion projects. Similarly, we also look for applicants to have a specific project that they want to work on during the trip. As we’re relatively unstructured (we don’t have a curriculum and won’t be telling you how to spend your time), it’s important for you to know what you want to work on and to have the skills to work on it in a self-directed way. This could be a full-time job, learning a new skill, or a side project.

We also look for people who have unique backgrounds and life experiences to share with the group. For example, tell us in your application if you led the linguistics community in compiling a dictionary for the Na’vi language, learned to code while supporting yourself by playing poker professionally, picked up Japanese by living in a monastery in Japan for 6 months, or spent several years working as a statistician in a hedge fund focusing on horse gambling. These are all examples of actual people who have come on our trips.

I’m not a programmer / designer / entrepreneur. Can I come?

If you’re a creative type that doesn’t work in tech (writer, architect, artist, etc.), that’s awesome! We love having other types of people on the trips.

In your application, tell us about your projects and why they are interesting (what are you doing that’s new and innovative?). Also, let us know that you’re comfortable hanging out with techies in a tech-focused community, as the majority of our professional talks are on topics like programming, design, and entrepreneurship.

If you’re non-technical and your main role isn’t generative (marketer, sales, project management), tell us in your application about things you’ve created or interesting life experiences you’ve had. This could be starting a company, building a blog, becoming a professional poker player, motorcycling through South America, or something else entirely. Also, tell us why you’re interested in being part of a tech community.

There are also a few types of people who we don’t typically accept:

  • Life coaches
  • Drop shippers
  • Affiliate marketers

People from these backgrounds have historically not been a good cultural fit for our community. However, we do keep an open mind, and make decisions on a person-by-person basis. If you do fall into one of the above categories, try and make sure your application is extremely strong in another area, by showing us a strong history of working on creative side projects outside of work or having some really interesting life experience (i.e., talk about how you’re writing a novel or how you spent several years living in Zimbabwe).

How is Hacker Paradise different than _____?

We’ve run trips to over 10 countries over the past 2 years, so we’ve worked out a lot of the kinks and have been working continuously to improve the participant experience (we still adapt and try new things each trip).

In that time, we’ve had 300+ people come on our trips, so we now have alumni in 35+ countries around the world. Wherever you go after the program, there’s likely either someone else traveling there or an alumni living there.

Also, the thing that I think is hard to understand until you’ve been on one of our trips is that Hacker Paradise ends up being an accelerator for personal and professional growth. More so than just arranging logistics to make it easier to work and travel, we actively screen for people who are working on creative and entrepreneurial projects, people who we think will add value to a creative professional community.

It’s an incredibly supportive, stimulating environment, and people will often leave the trip with new projects, ideas, and sometimes jobs or career directions. It’s also common for people to go on to hire each other or collaborate in other ways, even after the trip ends.

What’s a typical day / week like?

The Hacker Paradise program is built around a number of keystone events:

Monday lunch

This is a social event where everyone on the trip gets together to hang out and chat about what they’re working for the week. Food is on us.

Tuesday talks / events

On Tuesdays, we’ll typically organize some kind of professional event. This will usually be a series of talks given by people within the group, but we’ll also often organize events with the local tech scene. Talks are split about 50-50 between tech-related topics (i.e. intro to Meteor, writing about yourself and your product, bootstrapping abroad) and non-tech-related topics (mindfulness, the neurobiology of sleep, ethical tourism).

Thursday Demos / Reciprocity Ring

Each week on Thursdays, we alternate between two events. The first is group demos, where people can show what they’ve been working on and get feedback from the group. Demos also serve as a time to set goals and talk about ways to support each other through accountability.

The other is the Reciprocity Ring, which is an exercise where everyone in the group goes around and asks for at least 1 thing they could use help with from the group, personally or professionally. This exercise helps build a culture of giving within the community, and also helps people realize when there are others with similar interests (like learning a new programming language or getting in shape). This often results in people grouping up to work on their goals together.

Social Events

At least once a week, we’ll have a social event, where the group will come together and hangout. If we’re in a destination where we have kitchens & apartments, we’ll often do a big group potluck. If not, we’ll often do a big group dinner or happy hour followed by a game night. These events are a big part of why groups bond so closely and quickly on our trips.

Self-organized Events

Finally, there are a number of events each week that the community self-organizes around topics they’re interested in. In the past, we’ve had people organize running groups, meditation groups, writing groups, Pokemon Go trips, and a host of other activities. These vary from trip to trip, and are a great way to share your unique interests with the group!

Informally hanging out

One of the best parts about traveling with a group is that there are always people to hang out with! Pretty much anytime you want to go out to eat or visit a local attraction, you can find several people to go with you.

It’s all optional

Nothing is required on our trips, so you can find a rhythm that works for you. Some people will be really involved, and will be at every event. Others will spend more time to themselves, and only hit the main ones (Monday lunch, Tuesday talks, Thursday demos, and the weekly social event).

If you ever have a call that conflicts, or you want to spend some time alone, you’re free to do so! One of our facilitators may follow up and check in on you if they haven’t seen you in a few days just to make sure you’re okay, but as long as you’re alright, you’re free to participate as much or as little as makes sense for you.

That being said, we recommend diving in and getting super involved :)

Where are you going next and when are you announcing it?

We’re currently in Asia, and will be heading to South America in 2017! Check out our home page for more info about each trip. We’ll be announcing our destinations for summer 2017 and beyond early next year.

What’s included in the price?

The price includes accommodations, workspace, and community events. You’re responsible for your own flights, food, and entertainment expenses. Food and entertainment typically costs around $500-800 per month in locations like Southeast Asia, and $900-1200 per month in places like Europe and Asia, depending on your spending habits.

What will I do for transportation?

Once you’ve been accepted on a trip, we’ll pass along information about the accommodations and our recommendations for airport transport. Our housing options are typically within 10-20 minute walks of the workspace. Once on the ground, you’ll most likely be traveling places on foot or using public transit. People will also occasionally rent bicycles from local vendors.

item.title: South America -- here we come!
item.description:
We’re very excited to announce that, for the first time, Hacker Paradise will be going to South America! In order to have enough time to enjoy each location, we are going to be staying in a city for 8 weeks. That means twice as much culture, twice as much food, and twice as much adventure.

This is not a trip you want to miss.

PS – we just released our blog post with housing and coworking info for South America! You can find more details there after finishing up here :)

Buenos Aires, Argentina (January 8 - March 4)

A mix of Latin American and European influences, Buenos Aires is the cultural, political, and economic hub of Argentina. We will be centered in the Palermo neighborhood — affectionately called the Brooklyn of Buenos Aires — which is prime territory for shopping in boutique stores, discovering cozy coffee shops, and eating some of the best food Buenos Aires has to offer.

Get ready for summer! Average highs for the time we are there will be around 27 (80 F), while the average lows hover around 20 C (68 F).

Bite into a world-renowned Argentinian steak. Don’t forget the chimichurri sauce. Follow it up with some ice cream that is allegedly creamier than Italian gelato.

Take a stroll across the world’s widest avenue. Avenida 9 de Julio has 7 lanes in each direction and then is flanked with 4 additional parallel lanes on each side.

Hello, wine country. Swish some local malbec, shiraz, and cabernet sauvignon.

Been wanting to jump into the arts? Teatro Colón is considered to be one of the best opera houses in the world.

Homemade empanadas are waiting for you on almost every street corner. Also, try the medialunas, the Argentinian version of a croissant that is smaller and sweeter than its French cousin.

Bored with co-working spaces? Spend a day coworking at the El Ateneo Grand Splendid in Barrio Norte, one of the most beautiful bookstores in the world.

Itching to join in some local festivities? We will be in Buenos Aires during Carnival! Get ready to throw some water balloons and spray foam at passerbys.

Springboard to the beaches of Montevideo, the picturesque mountains in Patagonia, or go penguin watching in Ushuaia as you launch on an expedition to Antarctica.

Lima, Peru (March 12 - May 6)

One of the most overlooked cities of South America, Lima is a bustling metropolis nestled between the mountains and the ocean. We will be in the trendy Miraflores and Barranco neighborhoods with lots of places to eat, hang out, and explore. We’ll also be only 10-minutes from the beach!

Food, food, and more food. Peru has been awarded the World’s Leading Culinary Destination for the past 4 years in a row.

Get ready to eat some ceviche, raw fish marinated in citrus juice and spiced with chili peppers. The fish off the coast of Lima have a unique flavor due to the type of plankton located in the area so the taste is truly one-of-a-kind.

Relax while sipping a pisco sour, a South American classic cocktail concocted from a local grape brandy, lime juice, syrup, and egg whites.

We’re going to Lima during the clear, summer months, with daily highs from 24-28 C (75-83 F) and lows from 16-19 C (61-67 F). You Instagram will be overwhelmed with breath-taking sunset shots.

Being directly on the coast, Lima is loaded with plenty of beaches. Kick back on the sand, learn how to surf, or visit the islands off the Lima coast that are home to hundreds of sea lions.

The modern city of Lima has enveloped the ancient structures built before it. Archeological sites like Huaca Pucllana, a 7-story pyramid that predates the Incan empire by nearly 1000 years, are hidden gems tucked inside the sprawling city.

Need a rush of adrenaline? Get ready to paraglide by running off a 200-foot cliff to soar over the city with beautiful ocean on your left and skyscrapers on your right.

Machu Picchu, voted one of the Seven Wonders of the New World, is a must see–along with the Sacred Valley, and the Inca Trail. There have been talks of imposing legislation to close or restrict access to some of these areas so the time to go is now!

item.title: We're Hiring Another Trip Leader
item.description:
In short

Spend the next year traveling the world, starting in Asia this fall, while leading a ragtag crew of developers, designers, entrepreneurs, writers, project managers, and all-around cool people.

About the company

Hacker Paradise is a community of creative professionals that work while traveling the world. We organize trips to exciting locations for people who want to have new experiences and get stuff done at the same time, attracting freelancers, remote workers, entrepreneurs, and people who simply want to take some time off and learn something new or work on side-projects.

We live by the creed work hard, play hard.

About the position

We are looking for a Trip Leader to lead our Hacker Paradise fall trip that starts in September to Korea, Thailand, and Bali and wherever we decide to go after that (which you will have input on).

Your job is to make sure the trip runs smoothly and everyone has an awesome time. The job requires a deep understanding of who our participants are and what they are looking for.

A trip leader’s main goals are to:

  • Cultivate Community: People that participate in Hacker Paradise trips often end up working together and forging long-lasting bonds of friendship. It’s a Trip Leader’s job to connect people, keep the community engaged, and make sure Hacker Paradise remains a safe space for everyone to come together and contribute.

  • Support Growth: At Hacker Paradise, we highly value personal and professional growth. The Trip Leader works to understand the goals of each of our participants and tries to help them achieve those goals during the trip.

  • Keep things running smoothly: On the trip, there will be the day-to-day of keeping the program running while also dealing with the inevitable hiccups that come along the way. Part of the Trip Leader’s job is to handle and resolve all of this to ensure that participants have as smooth of an experience as possible and that logistics don’t get in the way of everything else.

Description of Responsibilities

Responsibilities for a facilitator fall into roughly two categories: facilitating on the ground and managing the community.

Here are some examples of facilitation responsibilities:

  • Organize group activities
    • Weekly talks & demos
    • Weekly lunches
  • Deal with Wi-Fi issues
  • Take care of the projector, the router, and other Hacker Paradise gear
  • Manage trip budget
  • Handle logistics for arrivals and departures & Handle issues regarding housing and co-working spaces

Here are some examples of community manager responsibilities:

  • Define the initial cultural goals/values of the group
  • Manage conflict within the community
  • Onboard and engage new members of the community
  • Connect with the local tech community through talks & events
  • Cultivate connections between members of the community
  • Interview potential candidates
  • Seek feedback from the group and iterate on our processes & structure
  • Help manage the Hacker Paradise social media
  • Be an active participant on Slack and at social events

What we’re looking for

We’re looking for people who can commit to a year of traveling & working with Hacker Paradise. This will be split into 3 distinct 3 month trips. Each trip will have 1-2 week-long breaks in the middle where you can recharge, and there will be 3-6 weeks in between trips.

We’re looking for people who have experience:

  • Organizing events (conferences, hackathons, meetups, etc.)
  • Working with creative and technical people (bonus points if you’re technical yourself)
  • Leading / managing groups of people(TA-ing in college, managing people, being a camp counselor, etc.)
  • Resolving conflict (non-violent communication, etc.)
  • Working with high autonomy, either professionally or on your own projects
  • Living or traveling abroad for extended periods

Compensation

The best part about Hacker Paradise for us has been the ability to (1) travel the world and (2) be part of a fantastic community, developing friendships that last far beyond the trips themselves.

In terms of financial compensation, you will receive free travel & housing when leading a trip and a stipend on top of that for living expenses during the trip.

Time Commitment

Your role should involve an average of 30 hours per week of formal work. Some weeks may involve more or less than that depending on activities, and there may be a fair amount of informal work (people asking you about logistics at dinner or during off-hours).

item.title: Explore Asia with us this fall!
item.description:
We’re excited to announce that, by popular request, we’ll be heading to Asia this fall! We’ll be visiting South Korea, Thailand, and Bali for great food and unforgettable cultural experiences. See below for more info on each location.

Jeju Island, South Korea (September 18 - October 15)

Jeju, often regarded as the “Korean Hawaii”, is 60 miles southwest of the southern tip of South Korea. It is an up-and-coming tech hot spot in Korea and boasts a warm climate, beautiful beaches, and tropical mountains.

Jeju’s landscape includes South Korea’s highest peak, dormant volcanoes, and underground lava tunnels. Here are some of the famed peaks of the island: Mt. Hallansan and Mt. Sanbang:

The early fall weather is outstanding in Jeju. The average high is 75 F (24 C) and the water temperature is 74 F (23 C), so we’ll be spending some time hanging out at the beach! Also, one of our facilitators is a Korean language and culture instructor, so you can pick up some Korean while you’re there!

Korean food is incredibly diverse, ranging from marinated BBQ to vegetarian delights to street food that will blow the socks off the Korean taco trucks you’ve eaten at before.

We will also hold some professional events with Kakao, one of South Korea’s top tech companies. They run a super popular instant messaging app in Asia (160 million users spread out over 230 countries), and are the company that acquired Path in 2015.

Perhaps the most exciting thing about this trip is that the local Jeju Government will be sponsoring free housing for everyone in the group, so you’ll just pay the Hacker Paradise program fee for this leg of the trip! Here’s the government-sponsored coworking space that will serve as our HQ during our time there:

PS - Korea has the fastest average Internet connection in the world :)

Chiang Mai, Thailand (October 23 - November 19)

We’re heading back to Chiang Mai for the second leg of our Asia tour, as it consistently ranks as people’s favorite destination whenever we go to Asia!

Tucked away in the beautiful mountains of northern Thailand, Chiang Mai is known for its incredible hiking and trekking, warm and welcoming locals, and a relaxing air of Buddhist spirituality.

While we are there, Chiang Mai will be celebrating the Thai Festival of Lights (November 13-15), a beautiful spectacle where thousands lanterns released into the sky. Check it out below - this is a bucket-list experience!

The Chiang Mai city area has over 300 Buddhist temples,70% is covered by mountains and vegetation, and is home to Thailand’s highest mountain.

Thailand is also the birthplace of Muay Thai. It’s also known as the ‘art of eight limbs,’ because boxers use elbows, knees, and shins in addition to their fists.

The weather in Chiang Mai is perfect in the fall. The cool season starts in November and is typified by dry weather and temperatures ranging from 60 F (15 C) to 80 F (25 C) in the valley.

Even though Thailand is overflowing with local culture and tradition, you’ll never be far from the homeland comforts you crave. We’ll be staying near Maya, a large Western-style mall, and Thailand has the second most 7-11s in the world (Japan is the only country with more).

Also, we should mention that Thai food in Thailand is absolutely amazing. Here’s a picture of Khao Soi, a popular dish in the North:

Ubud, Bali (November 20 - December 17)

Everybody loves Bali! Popularized by the book Eat, Pray, Love, Bali is renowned as a community for yoga / meditation, as well as a mecca for surfers with a rich cultural and natural landscape.

After arriving in Bali, you’ll quickly become a millionaire – in Indonesian rupiah! 1 USD is about equal to 13,100 IDR, so you’ll have more rupiahs then you know what to do with.

Ubud, where we’ll be staying, is probably the yoga capital of the world. Whether you’re a beginner or an expert, you can find a range of classes in all different types of yoga, as well as workshops in other meditation and spiritual practices, such as ecstatic dance.

In Bali, you can also partake in a cup of the world’s rarest and most expensive coffee. Kopi Luwak is created from coffee beans that have passed through the digestive system of the cat-like Indonesian civet.

Bali is also the perfect jumping off point for the 921 other inhabited islands in Indonesia. If you’re feeling adventurous, you could also venture off to one of the estimated 16,586 uninhabited islands in the archipelago and plant the Hacker Paradise flag.

We highly recommend taking a weekend during your stay to climb Mount Batur, one of Bali’s twin active volcanoes, to watch the sunrise. You can also venture to Pura Besakih, a large temple the overlooks Mt. Agung, Bali’s other active volcano.

Also, get your SLR camera and your Instagram account ready for lots of beautiful temples & sunsets.

item.title: Hacker Paradise - Tokyo Drift
item.description:
When we first arrived in Tokyo, we weren’t sure exactly what to expect. We were excited to see a whole new culture few of us had explored before. We never really truly realized what we would find.

It’s hard to think of a city we’ve been to so far that has been as electric as Tokyo, Japan. Whether it was riding the Shinkansen bullet trains, meeting the creator of Ruby, or hitting up the Tsukiji Fish Market at 4am for tuna sashimi that’s so fresh it’s almost breathing, there was never a dull moment at Hacker Paradise - Tokyo.

Tokyo HQ: CASE Shinjuku

CASE Shinjuku and its incredibly courteous and friendly staff became our new home and family in Japan. This beautiful, clean, modern coworking space was complete with new furniture, great ambient music and fun extendo-outlets that hang down from the ceiling, was the perfect space to work from.

Operation: Food-Indulgence

A sushi train! A sushi train! Our kingdom for another sushi train! From the succulent and delicious katsu-don, to the group-favourite conveyor belt sushi, the food in Japan was world-class. It’s hard to beat beautifully-cheap, fresh sushi come on an express train bound for your table.

Some of us were spirited away

Being dunked into the inkwell of Hayao Miyazaki imagination in the Studio Ghibli museum was awe-inspiring. With his colorful photography-inspired landscapes covering the walls, it was difficult not to get sucked into a world of fantasy, magic, and traditional Japanese culture.

Halloween was a big deal

Halloween was not something we expected in Japan. As it turned out, Halloween was only brought to and commercialized in Japan about 4 years ago. Because of this, it was a huge deal in Tokyo with parties every weekend throughout the whole month of October and topped off with hoards of elaborate costumes flocking to the streets. Our crew followed suit.

Some pretty awesome guest speakers

While we were in Tokyo, we had the pleasure of learning about the startup scene from Disrupting Japan’s Tim Romero, Patrick McKenzie, CEO of Starfighter; and Yukihiro Matsumoto (Matz), creator of Ruby.

Sound like fun? Then check out our upcoming Southeast Asia 2016 trip to Vietnam, Indonesia, and Thailand. You can find out more on our home page or apply here.

item.title: Announcing our Contributor Program
item.description:
Hacker Paradise is a great experience for developers, designers, and entrepreneurs who want to travel and meet awesome people. Our past participants have launched really cool projects, and many of them end up making friends for life. Some of them even end up working together.

Since it takes a lot of work behind the scenes to screen everyone, scout hotels, and facilitate the community, our trips cost more than traveling on your own. For many people, the added value of being part of this tight-knit tech community on the road is more than worth it, and they’re happy to contribute financially to keep the community going.

However, we realize that there people out there who have a lot to contribute to the community, but don’t have as much financial freedom. Some examples of people in this group are students, people who work for non-profits, bootstrapping entrepreneurs, and people from the developing world - all may be talented and awesome, and yet still have a hard time pulling together the funds to come on one of our trips.

We’ve been thinking for awhile about we can reach out to these communities and make Hacker Paradise more accessible for them in a way that aligns with our values, as we believe that having a diverse group benefits everyone on the trip.

As a result, today, we’re happy to announce that we’re launching an experimental Contributor Program, where people can trade skilled work for Hacker Paradise in exchange for a discount on their program fee.

The idea is that while some people contribute financially to keep the community going, skilled people who have less cash available can make in-kind contributions to the community instead. In exchange for 3-5 hours per week of work, contributors will get 50% off the Hacker Paradise program fee (not including housing). Here’s how it compares:

What would you work on? Ideally, you’d propose a couple of projects, and then we’d work together to find something along those lines that is both fair and benefits Hacker Paradise or the broader community. Here are some examples of possible projects you could work on:

  • Organizing a BarCamp or other major event
  • Helping us build / maintain internal software tools (Rails, Jekyll, etc.)
  • Helping us automate / improve our internal processes
  • Writing posts for our blog
  • Helping us with social media or other marketing initiatives
  • Helping us with scouting or other operational work
  • Help us with a logo, infographic, or other design asset

We’ll be trying out the program with a limited number of slots for our fall batch to Japan / Taiwan, and then may continue it in the spring and beyond. If interested, please apply using this form.

We also still have some external diversity grants available. If interested in those, please check them out here.

item.title: Barcelona Highlights
item.description:
Barcelona is known for three things: beach, culture, and nightlife.

Coincidentally, our first week in Barcelona coincided with Running of the Bulls, and a few of the more adventurous members of our group joined in:

We quickly settled into our new home at Betahaus, Barcelona. It’s a cool space with a good vibe, but the highlight of our trip was the rooftop terrace, which gave breathtaking sunset views of the city. Many nights were spent hanging out up there.

Barcelona is also well-known for its street art. The one rule in street art is: “Don’t paint over someone’s tag with a lesser piece.” As a result, local store owners will pay for prominent street artists to paint their doors and so that they don’t become defaced with low quality tags. This was our favorite piece we came across:

Another great thing about Barcelona is the nightlife! People explored salsa, saw David Guetta live at a local music festival, and ate oh so many tapas:

Partway through the month, we co-hosted an event with one Typeform, a local venture-backed startup with ~40 employees. Members of both the Typeform and Hacker Paradise teams gave informative talks on web-performance, deep-learning, and dealing with impostor syndrome.

People would use the mornings to relax on the beach or to explore the architectural works of Antoni Gaudi, in particular his Park Güell and the famed Sagrada Familia.

On one of the last weekends, we took a cable-car ride up to Monserrat Abbey and hiked along the Sant Jeroni trail. Along the way, we took in breathtaking panoramic views of Catalonia.

Towards the end of the month, we held a group-wide hackathon. One team built an app to help prevent poaching in Africa, the Anti-Poaching Map.

The team was led by Tim Masson, an engineer and entrepreneur from the U.K. who has spent the last 15 years living in Zimbabwe, and 6 other developers, designers, and content creators came on board.

Within a day, the site came together, and the team has continued working on it since, recently launching an IndieGoGo campaign.
